title: Using the single-cell imaging system and orthotropic footpad injection to establish mouse models for experimental and spontaneous melanoma metastasis

Protocol for a single-cell imaging system to track metastatic cell survival in vivo
Timing: 2 days
This section describes the protocol of the single-cell image system to track the fate of fluorescently labeled single tumor cells reaching the lung. Upon completing the section, the early survival of metastatic tumor cells arriving in the lung has been determined and quantified. The protocol can be applied to any tumor cells.
Label B16F1 tumor cells: 2 h.
Note: Before labeling tumor cells, dissolve the lyophilized CMFDA in DMSO to a stock concentration of 10 mM. Dilute the stock solution to a working concentration of 5 μM in a serum-free medium.
Tumor cell line preparation.
Culture tumor cells to a confluency of 60%–70% (3 dish-175 cm).
Note: Make sure to have enough cells for in vivo injections the next day.
Remove the cultural media.
Wash cells with Phosphate-Buffered Saline (PBS) 2 times.
Gently add 5 mL of 5 μM CMFDA working solution in a 175 cm dish.
Incubate for 30 min under growth conditions of 37°C and 5% CO2 in a cell culture incubator.
Gently remove the CMFDA working solution, and wash with PBS 2 times.
Add cell culture media and incubate for another 30 min in the same cell culture condition in a cell culture incubator.
Image labeled cells as a pre-labeled in vitro group using green (emission 517 nm and excitation 492 nm) filters under fluorescence microscopy.
Collect the labeled cells in 5 × 106 cells/mL in serum-free media and keep them on ice for tail vein injection into mice.
Injection of labeled tumor cells: 30–45 min

Note: After labeled cells are collected, 1 × 106 cells (200 μL of 5 × 106 cells/mL) are immediately delivered to mice (5 mice per condition group) by tail vein injection using a 27 1/2-GA needle.
Prepare the mice: place mice under a heating light to maintain body temperature.
Load the syringe with a 27/ 1/2-GA needle and draw the tumor cells into a sterile syringe.
Locate the vein.
Gently restrain the mouse by holding its tail using a mouse restraining device.
Note: The tail vein can usually be seen through the skin as a thin blue line.
Grasp the tail firmly just below the area where you will be injecting and disinfect the area with alcohol.
Insert the needle into the vein at a shallow angle (less than 30 degrees) and advance it about 1–2 mm (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A).

Figure 1. Diagram of the single-cell imaging system to track the survival of metastatic cells reaching the lung
(A) Tail vein cell delivery.
(B) Lung insufflation.
(C) Representation of images of labeled tumor cells reached the lung at 1-, 6- and 24-h time points after injection. The total number of labeled tumor cells at the 1-h time point was presented 100%. The percent of metastatic survival was determined by normalizing the mean number of cells at 6 or 24 h with the mean number of cells at 1 h for each mouse lung. Scale bars: 200 μm.
Aspirate to confirm that the needle is in the vein, then slowly inject 200 μL of cells into the vein of the mouse. Be sure to inject slowly and avoid causing damage to the vein.
Note: Aspiration is tricky. A gently negative pressure applies to the plunger to avoid introducing possible bubbles.

Remove the needle gently and apply pressure to the injection site with a sterile gauze pad to stop any bleeding. Continue until all groups of mice are completed (10–20 mice per group).
Monitor the mice closely for any signs of distress or adverse effects following the injection.
Note: Tail vein injections should only be performed by trained personnel with appropriate ethical approval and in compliance with institutional and regulatory guidelines.
Euthanize the mice at 1, 6, or 24 h after injection. Five mice were injected per cell line per time point.
Note: Euthanize the mice by CO2 inhalation with an initial 30%–60% flow rate for 2–3 min to minimize stress to the mouse breathing and lungs, then increase the CO2 flow rate by 70%–90% for an extra 2 min. The euthanasia steps are critical to prevent any lung hemorrhage and alveoli breakage caused by a high flow rate of CO2.
Lung insufflation (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B). 10–30 min.
Set up the insufflation apparatus using a 20 mL syringe connected to a 35 mL Extension Set Priming Volume, DEHP-Free and Latex-Free Male and Female luer locks with Slide Clamp to monitor PBS volume and flow rate.
Consistency of insufflation of the lungs to the right size without under or over insufflation with PBS (approximately volume per lung 0.75–1.0 mL).
Spray the mice with 70% alcohol before placing them in the tissue culture hood for lung extraction.
A mid-transverse skin incision is made at the mid-abdominal area and the skin should be pulled over in opposite directions (cranial-caudal) to expose the thoracic and abdominal cavities.
Make an incision on the ventral midabdominal line alba close to the xiphoid process, then follow with an incision into the abdominal cavity to expose the mouse diaphragm.
Cut into the mouse diaphragm without lacerating the lungs.

Make a bilateral incision along the sternum to the first rib cage.
Pull the sternum cranially to expose the trachea.
Canulate the trachea at the intercartilaginous ligament with a 20G × 1″ IV Angio-catheter approximately 1/2 inch.
Remove the stylet needle and advance the catheter.
Place a single loose suture with 2-0 Vicryl underneath the proximal trachea and leave the suture loose.
Connect the extension IV set primed with PBS into the IV catheter and hold it in place.
Note: the lungs will be expanded approximately 30–45 seconds after insufflation is completed.
Lock the IV set with the slide clamp.
Slightly pull IV catheter.
Gently tie up the distal trachea with 2-0 Vicryl suture without rupturing it to avoid any leakage of insufflated PBS.
Note: This will prevent the mouse lung from collapsing.
Dissect the mouse lungs surgically.
Cut the trachea distally without compromising the suture on the trachea.
Use the trachea or hold the mouse heart with a thumb dressing forceps to dissect the lungs out using straight iris scissors.
Cut the lung mediastinal ligamentum.
Cut the attachment of the diaphragm that connects to the mouse liver and gently remove the lungs.
Place and rinse the mouse lung in cold PBS for 30–45 s to get rid of any blood debris.
The lungs (L1, L2. L3, L4, L5) are then immediately transferred into a 50 mL conical tube containing 35 mL PBS at 4°C supplemented with penicillin 100 U/mL/streptomycin 10 μg/mL for surface fluoresce microscopy imaging on a Leica DM IRB Widefield Fluorescence Microscope equipped with a filter set appropriate for imaging green fluorescent protein (GFP).

Note: Each mouse lung was imaged one time only per each time point at 1 h, 6 h, and 24 h by taking 10 random surface fluorescent pictures of each single mouse lung (L1, L2, L3, L4, L5) using Improvision's Openlab 3.1 scientific image acquisition software, then all lung pictures were saved until ready to be analyzed and quantified. In addition, Improvision's Openlab 3.1 scientific image acquisition software was programmed to read and analyze each event at a size of 10 photons or greater, any event smaller than 10 photons was not read or analyzed; this was considered an artifact or background noise (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C).
After imaging each timepoint (1 h, 6 h, 24 h), place all five lungs in a 50 mL conical tube filled with 35 mL of 10% formaldehyde buffered for H&E analysis.
Images analysis.
Use Improvision's Openlab 3.1 scientific image acquisition software to analyze and quantify the total sum of the surface fluorescent area in the 10 images of each single mouse lung (L1, L2, L3, L4, L5) per timepoint.
Use Microsoft Excel to graph the average number of all five-lung surface fluorescent events (L1, L2, L3, L4, L5) at 1 h, 6 h, 24 h.
Subtract the average number of each timepoint at 6 h, 24 hr from the average baseline number at 1 h timepoint.
Note: Quantification of lung fluorescent events was validated using both enumeration of surface fluorescent event counts and mean fluorescent area.

Statistical analysis: Nonparametric t-test and ANOVA were used for image analysis. Statistical analyses were performed using GraphPad Prism version 3.0 for Macintosh (GraphPad Software). The percent metastatic survival is determined by normalizing the mean number of cells at 6 h or 24 h with the mean number of cells at 1 h for each mouse lung (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C). Statistical significance was defined as P ≤ 0.05.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1],5[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5],6[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6],7[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]
Establishment of experimental melanoma metastasis model by tail vein injection
Timing: 3 weeks
This section describes the procedure to develop the experimental metastasis model by tail vein injection. Upon completion of the section, the metastatic potential of tumor cells has been measured quickly and easily. The protocol can be applied to any tumor cells.
Tumor cells preparation: 1 h.
Note: Tumor cell lines should be cultured to a 70%–85% confluency.
Trypsinize tumor cells, and centrifuge down with 1200 rpm for 5 min.
Wash the tumor cells with 10 mL serum-free media.
Resuspend the tumor cells in serum-free media at a concentration of 2.5 × 106/mL for B16F1, and 5 × 106 for A375 cells and keep the cells on ice for injection as soon as possible.
Tumor cells injection: 1–2 h.
Prepare the mice: place mice under a heating light to maintain body temperature.
Load the syringe with a 27/ 1/2-GA needle and draw the tumor cells into a sterile syringe.
Locate the vein.
Gently restrain the mouse by holding its tail using a mouse restraining device.
Note: The tail vein can usually be seen through the skin as a thin blue line.
Grasp the tail firmly just below the area where you will be injecting and disinfect the area with alcohol.
Insert the needle into the vein at a shallow angle (less than 30 degrees) and advance it about 1–2 mm (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).

Figure 2. Diagram of experimental metastasis model by tail vein injection
(A) Tail vein injection of 5 × 105 B16F1-PTENΔLP tumor cells.
(B) Lung metastases 3 weeks after injection.
(C) Images of a lung section with micrometastases. Scale bars: 1 cm.
Aspirate to confirm that the needle is in the vein, then slowly inject 200 μL of cells into the vein of the mouse.
Note: Be sure to inject slowly and avoid causing damage to the vein.
Remove the needle gently and apply pressure to the injection site with a sterile gauze pad to stop any bleeding.
Note: Continue until all groups of mice are completed (10–20 mice per group).
Monitor the mice closely for any signs of distress or adverse effects following the injection.
Check tumor metastasis.
Three weeks after the transplantation of tumor cells, euthanize the mice with CO2.
Dissect the mouse from the ventral side.
Inject the fixing solution of 10% Buffered Formalin Phosphate into the lung through the trachea.
Visually count the number of macro-metastases in the lung.
Transfer the lung with tumor metastasis in the 10% Buffered Formalin Phosphate fixing solution.
Note: The fixed lungs should also be paraffin-embedded and sectioned for H&E staining for counting micro-metastasis under the microscopy (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1],8[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]
Note: Tail vein injections should only be performed by trained personnel with appropriate ethical approval and in compliance with institutional and regulatory guidelines.
Establishment of the spontaneous metastasis model by an orthotropic footpad injection
Timing: 6 weeks
This section describes that the spontaneous metastasis model by the orthotropic footpad injection can more completely mimic the actual complexity of the metastatic process and is more relevant to assess distant metastases.
Tumor cells preparation: 1–2 h.
Note: Tumor cell lines should be cultured to a 70%–85% confluency.

Trypsinize tumor cells, collect the tumor cells in 10 mL culture media, and centrifuge down with 1200 rpm for 5 min.
Wash tumor cells with 10 mL serum-free media, resuspend in serum-free media at a concentration of 5 × 107 cells/mL, and keep on ice for the next step as soon as possible.
Footpad injection: 1–2 h.
Fill a syringe with a 30-GA needle with the appropriate amount of cells to be administered.
Note: The amount that can be injected into a footpad is 20 μL per mouse.
Place the mouse in a restraining device with one hind foot isolated and extended by gently grasping the skin above the stifle.
Wipe the foot with alcohol to sterilize and remove debris before injecting.
Hold the toes of the extended foot before releasing the skin at the stifle.
Inject 20 μL tumor cells subcutaneously into the center of the hind footpad at a shallow angle (less than 30 degrees) and slowly advance it about 2–3 mm (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).

(A) 1 × 106 A375p ENTPD5 tumor cells were delivered by footpad injection.
(B) Representative image of mice with the local foot tumor (white arrow) at 6 weeks after footpad injection.

Note: This is the critical step; any leakage will affect the result (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).
Remove the needle and observe for bleeding.
Apply light pressure to the puncture site if bleeding occurs.
Return the animals to the cage.

Monitor the animal: Watch the animal closely for any signs of distress or adverse effects following the injection.
Check the metastasis (Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]).

Six weeks after injection, euthanize the mice with CO2.
Lay the ventral side up of the mouse and dissect it.
Inject the fixing solution of 10% Buffered Formalin Phosphate into the lung through the trachea and visually count the number of macro-metastases in the lung.
Count the number of metastases in other organs.
Fix the organs with tumor metastasis in the 10% Buffered Formalin Phosphate fixing solution.
Note: The organs with metastatic tumors can also be sectioned for H&E staining for counting micro-metastasis under a microscope (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1],2[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2],9[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9]
Note: Footpad injections should only be performed by trained personnel with appropriate ethical approval and in compliance with institutional and regulatory guidelines. Also, note that the volume of injection should be limited to no more than 50 μL to avoid overloading the footpad, which can cause tissue damage and pain to the animal.
Analysis of the metastasis
Tumor numbers are obtained by visual inspection of tissues in mice euthanized 3 weeks (tail vein injection) or 6 weeks (footpad injection) post-transplantation. Micrometastases should be counted by a pathologist's evaluation after the dissection of the lung. Statistical analyses can be performed as follows: unpaired t-test (two-tailed) for all column datasets. The p-values of less than 0.05 are considered statistically significant.
